body.p: It would not be feasible to stipulate in an accounting standard that an adjustment to take account of non‑transferability is necessary only if the employees cannot mitigate the effects of non‑transferability through the use of other derivatives. However, using expected life as an input into an option pricing model, or modelling early exercise in a binomial or similar model, copes with both situations. If employees were able to mitigate the effects of non‑transferability by using derivatives, this would often result in the employee share options being exercised later than they would otherwise have been. By taking this factor into account, the estimated fair value of the share option would be higher, which makes sense, given that non‑transferability is not a constraint in this case. If the employees cannot mitigate the effects of non‑transferability through the use of derivatives, they are likely to exercise the share options much earlier than is optimal. In this case, allowing for the effects of early exercise would significantly reduce the estimated value of the share option.
